answers: Arthur Pigou [or Arthur Cecil Pigou; accept Pigouvian tax]
parts: Name this economist whose namesake taxes can provide a double dividend by discouraging socially damaging behavior and using the tax proceeds to solve other social problems.
Pigovian taxes can correct market failures from the negative form of these things, the difference between the private and social cost of an action.

Pigou’s Real Balance effect hypothesizes that deflation causes demand, output and employment all to rise. This economist studied deflation during the Great Depression and preceded Janet Yellen as Fed Chair.
Name this man whose best-known feat was accomplished in conjunction with William Dawes, helping Samuel Adams and John Hancock avoid capture.
Paul Revere was intercepted by British forces before he could get to this town. Along with Lexington, this town names a battle in which the “shot heard round the world” started the Revolutionary War.
After the war, Revere founded the first American rolling mill for this good. Three Gilded Age “Kings” who fought for control of this good included Marcus Daly, the founder of Anaconda Mining Company.

answers: optical path length [accept optical path length difference, OPLD, or optical distance; prompt on geometric distance or length]

attenuated total internal reflection [or TIR; accept attenuated total reflection, attenuated total reflectance, or ATR-FTIR spectroscopy; accept frustrated total internal reflection; prompt on reflection]
parts: Name this quantity changed in a Michelson interferometer to produce a range of frequencies for Fourier transform IR spectroscopy. This quantity is determined by both geometric parameters and the index of refraction.
FTIR (“F-T-I-R”) spec can use the attenuation of evanescent waves produced by this phenomenon to minimize the extinction produced by path length inside a sample.
One of these objects is moved in order to change the path length in an interferometer. These objects rely on conventional reflection to reverse the direction of incoming light.

answers: newspapers [accept news media or news industry; accept periodicals; prompt on publishing or publishers; prompt on media; prompt on printing or printers]
The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints [accept LDS Church; accept Mormon Church or Mormons]
parts: Name these institutions that include The Christian Science Monitor. While working at The Monitor, Kay Fanning became the first female editor of a national one of these institutions.
In a 2019 editorial, this evangelical magazine founded by Billy Graham called for Donald Trump’s impeachment, citing its 1998 editorial on Clinton’s impeachment.
This church publishes the Deseret (“dez-uh-RET”) News, which takes its name from a historical unrecognized U.S. state.
Identify this Tony-winning dance choreographer of The Pajama Game and Chicago. He emphasized the use of “jazz hands” for his dancers.
Fosse choreographed this sports musical, whose song “Whatever Lola Wants” was inspired by a dancer and mistress of Bavaria’s King Ludwig I.

Fosse included multiple dance styles for the 1959 musical Redhead, including this one still widely performed by chorus lines. This once-scandalous French dance features vigorous high-kicks and is performed in Jacques Offenbach’s Orpheus in the Underworld.

answers: Arabian Nights’ Entertainment [or One Thousand and One Nights; or Kitab alf Layla wa Layla]
parts: Name this brother of Kassim who uses the magic words “Open Sesame” in one story.
Scheherazade tells the story of Ali Baba to her husband Shahriyar to delay her execution in this collection of folktales.
In the tale of Ali Baba, this slave protects her master by pouring boiling oil on thirty-seven men hiding in leather jars.

answers: Xhosa (“ko-sa”) cattle killing movement [accept equivalents; prompt on Chiefs Plot or Grey’s Plot]
South Africa [or Republic of South Africa]
Shaka Zulu [or Tshaka; or Chaka; or Shaka kaSenzangakhona]
parts: Name this practice that was undertaken by one ethnic group to drive the British out and end “lung sickness.” Instead, this practice resulted in a large famine in the British Kaffraria.
The Xhosa (“ko-sa”) undertook the cattle killing movement in this modern-day country. It was later led by Nelson Mandela.
After the death of his mother, Nandi, this man ordered thousands of cows to be slaughtered and banned milk drinking. This chieftain developed the successful “bull horn” formation.

answers: Vladimir Nabokov [or Vladimir Vladimirovich Nabokov; or Vladimir Sirin]
parts: Name this character whose story is told by Vladimir Vladimirovich. He is ultimately fired from his position in the Russian department at Waindell College by Dr. Hagen.
Pnin is a novel by this Russian-American author of Lolita.

The final chapter of Pnin reveals the narrator to be Vladimir Vladimirovich, a man interested in these creatures, a recurring interest of Nabokov’s. In 2016, Yale University Press published Nabokov’s scientific drawings of these creatures.

answers: rRNA [accept ribosomal RNA; accept “ribonucleic acid” in place of “RNA”; prompt on RNA or ribonucleic acid; do not accept or prompt on “ribosome”]
parts: Name this highest taxonomic rank. The three categories in this rank are Archaea, Bacteria, and Eukarya.

Woese’s discovery of Archaea used his analysis of the gene coding for the 16S example of this molecule. The 16S and 23S examples of these molecules form the 30S and 50S subunits of a larger structure.
In Archaea, this phospholipid-based structure contains ether-linked lipids instead of ester-linked ones, and sometimes contains a monolayer in place of a lipid bilayer.
Bill Haslam, the former governor of this state, was once the U.S.’s wealthiest elected official. Bill Lee now governs this state, the only one with a free community college program.
Jim Justice, the governor of this state, is also its wealthiest private citizen. Justice made his fortune in coal, which was once the key industry of this Appalachian state south of Pennsylvania.
This governor’s fortune was made through the Plumpjack Winery. This governor’s violations of his own COVID rules to attend a fundraiser at the French Laundry have endangered his political career.

answers: Sierra Leone [or Republic of Sierra Leone; or Salone]
China [or People's Republic of China] (The quote is from Mao.)
parts: Women householders in this British colony had the right to vote since 1792, although those rights were restricted over time. This West African colony received over 50,000 “recaptives” between 1807 and 1864.
Unlike a larger neighbor, indigenous Maori women were not excluded from this country’s pioneering 1893 women’s suffrage bill.

Women’s suffrage advocates in this country broke the windows of its Parliament in 1912 but weren’t granted the technical right to vote until 1947. Women in this country were later said to “hold up half the sky.”
Name this non-Haydn composer, who wrote an E major trumpet concerto for Anton Weidinger.
Hummel published a “Complete Theoretical and Practical Course of Instruction on the Art of Playing” this instrument. Today, this instrument has 88 black and white keys.

Hummel taught pianist Louise Farrenc, who only began receiving equal pay as a composer after having one of her pieces premiered by Joseph Joachim (“YO-zef YO-ah-kim”), a player of this instrument. Modern players of this instrument include Janine Jansen (“ja-NEEN YON-sin”) and Hilary Hahn.

answers: spontaneous combustion [accept descriptive equivalents like bursting into flames; prompt on burning or combustion]
parts: A crowd laps up wine from a broken cask on the streets of Paris, foreshadowing the French Revolution, in a famous passage of this Dickens novel. It opens with “It was the best of times, it was the worst of times.”
This scheming Dickens villain encourages Mr. Wickfield’s drinking problem in an effort to marry his daughter Agnes and take over his law office.
In a Dickensian attack on alcoholism from Bleak House, a penchant for gin causes the rag and bone man Krook to suffer this unfortunate fate, whose plausibility is addressed in the novel’s preface.

answers: asteroids [accept asteroid belt; accept planetoids or minor planets]
orbital resonance with Neptune [accept resonant trans-Neptunian objects or resonant TNOs; prompt on being inside the Kuiper belt or beyond Neptune by asking “what property does their orbit have?”]
parts: The discovery of Pallas, Juno, and their many small companions forced scientists to create this new category to contain them, returning the number of planets to seven.
In 1846, the French and British agreed to share credit for the prediction and discovery of this eighth planet, which is still considered one today.

In contrast, newcomer Pluto was deprived of planet status by the IAU after the discovery of other trans-Neptunian objects and is now in a category defined by this orbital property. Objects with this property include the plutinos and twotinos.

answers: the plague [or bubonic plague; prompt on black death]
parts: Identify this weeks-long annual celebration where Venetians donned masks such as the bauta, which was later featured in Stanley Kubrick’s Eyes Wide Shut.
Beak-nosed masks were used by Venetian physicians to avoid contracting this disease. Perhaps 200 million people died during a “great” outbreak of this disease in the 14th century.

Another Venetian tradition, the Marriage to the Sea, concluded with the doge consecrating one of these objects. Pope Alexander III gave one of these objects to a Venetian doge for fighting a campaign against Frederick Barbarossa.

answers: spleen [accept The Spleen of Paris or “Spleen and Ideal”]
dice [or die; or dés; accept The Dice Cup or “A Throw of the Dice Will Never Abolish Chance”]
parts: Give this genre of poetry written in paragraphs rather than lines. It is named for a form of writing contrasted with verse.
Charles Baudelaire declares “Be Drunk!” in a prose poetry collection titled for this melancholic concept. The first section of Baudelaire’s Les Fleurs du Mal pits this concept against the Ideal.

Max Jacob wrote a collection of Cubist prose poems titled for a “cup” of these objects. Jacob was inspired by a Stéphane Mallarmé poem in free verse about these objects that experiments with typography.

answers: Vincent Van Gogh’s ear [prompt on ear by asking “whose ear?”]
Paul Gauguin [or Eugène Henri Paul Gauguin]
parts: Identify this object that is missing from a self-portrait in which the artist wears a green jacket and smokes a pipe.
Van Gogh may have severed his ear due to a conflict with this fellow artist in Arles (“arl”). This post-Impressionist painter of The Yellow Christ later moved to Tahiti.

Surrealist Meret (“MEH-ret”) Oppenheim sculpted this artist’s ear, replacing the earlobe with a fist. Henri Cartier-Bresson photographed this artist maneuvering a work among his numerous spindly-looking sculptures.
Identify this three-word phrase that first appeared spoken by the “madman” in Section 125 of The Gay Science.
The Gay Science was written by this German philosopher who also wrote Beyond Good and Evil.

In The Gay Science, Nietzsche uses this two-word Latin phrase to denote his “formula for greatness in a human being.” Nietzsche defines this attitude as "not merely bearing what is necessary… but loving it."
Name this giantess, a daughter of Thiazzi who married the sea god Niord.

The prose afterword to the Lokasenna says that it was Skadi who placed one of these animals above the bound Loki. Another of these animals, Jörmungandr (“YOR-mun-gahn-dur”), is so long that it encircles the world and bites its own tail.

Skadi was given the right to choose a husband from among the gods, but was only allowed to look at these body parts of theirs before choosing. As a result, Skadi ended up choosing Niord rather than Baldr.
Identify this technology co-developed by Yoshino, Stanley Whittingham, and John Goodenough, all three of whom received the 2019 Nobel Prize in Chemistry.
Yoshino used the petroleum coke to hold lithium ions in this part of the battery, through which the current flows into an electrical device, unlike the cathode.
Lithium ions may also be intercalated between sheets of this material consisting of sheets of hexagonally arranged carbon atoms.

answers: rice [prompt on food or crops or grain or harvest]
parts: Identify this shrine that houses the Sacred Mirror behind four wooden barriers. Princess Ōku is held to be the first Saiō (“sigh-oh”), a royal high priestess, to serve at this shrine.
The Ise Shrine is dedicated to Amaterasu, a kami from this Japanese religion.

The Ise Shrine is the site of the annual Kannamesai (“kahn-nah-meh-sigh”) Festival, during which the emperor personally offers some of this stuff to Amaterasu. The kami Inari is named after a “load” of this stuff, and patronizes this stuff’s production.
